name: (1E)-5-(4-methylphenyl)-1-phenylhex-1-en-3-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1028
Reason: The target compound has a benzene ring as a base structure, which typically has a melting point around 5.5 °C. The compound in question has two phenyl groups and one enone group. Each phenyl group adds structural rigidity and increases van der Waals interactions, potentially increasing the melting point. The phenyl groups are each estimated to raise the melting point by about 20 °C due to these effects. The enone group (a conjugated carbonyl and alkene) will contribute significantly to the melting point due to polarizability and possible hydrogen bonding with the carbonyl oxygen, contributing an increase of approximately 40 °C. The presence of the methyl groups on the phenyl rings adds minimal steric hindrance and very slight increase in molecular weight, which may contribute an additional 5 °C each. Summing the contributions, we have an estimated total increase of 90 °C from the base benzene structure. However, there can be interactions such as π-π stacking between the aromatic rings or cross-conjugation effects which are not entirely predictable quantitatively, so the predicted value will be slightly lower than the sum.
Test (Predicted reason):
The target compound (1E)-5-(4-methylphenyl)-1-phenylhex-1-en-3-one has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The presence of a ketone group (C=O) generally increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at +20 degrees. The presence of two phenyl rings adds to the molecular weight and rigidity of the molecule, which can increase the melting point, estimated at +10 degrees per phenyl group. The methyl group attached to the phenyl ring also increases the molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at +5 degrees. The conjugation of the double bond in the alkene group (C=C) may slightly increase the melting point due to increased rigidity, estimated at +5 degrees. The overall prediction is the sum of these effects.
##Prediction: 90.0
